linklist.link: Ability: Gift From an Accursed Tome 2d10+2

id-00111.traits_name1: If the ceramic horse’s rider has the Otherworldly Grace trait, the ceramic horse also has that trait.

id-00112.effect: The cloak shifts up to 2 squares.
id-00112.name: Shadow Elf Cloak

notes.p: Children of the Twilight Celestials, the shadow elves are the native denizens of the parasitic manifold of Equinox, also known as Dusk. Theirs is a world of perpetual twilight, a sun that never rises nor sets, a world that knows neither noon nor midnight.
Equinox is a dying world. The shadow elves plan to use their magic to rewrite Orden’s topography, creating a new home with themselves as rulers over all. In

Shadow elves are lit by an unseen sun. In places like Orden, they appear washed out, silhouetted, or grayscale. In Equinox, they have lived in the shadow of their manifold’s eternal dusk, making them incompatible with other light sources. Their skills, magic, and weapons do not fare well in the sun. But in turn, they can blend in with existing darkness and dissolve out of sight.

The shadow elves have mastered the art of combining deep, ancient magic with cutting-edge technology. Their weaponsmiths craft blades of solid shadow that strike and wound in many dimensions at once. A creature hit by one of these blades is injured in multiple worlds at a time. Only a victim of strong mind can compartmentalize and end these effects on their body in the here and now.

When the shadow elves invade Orden, they often ride domesticated dwimmerbeasts known as brush stalkers—quadrupeds who carry entire ecosystems on their rack of antlers. Newly born brush stalkers do not survive translation into Orden, so the ones the shadow elves ride are old: overgrown with bioluminescent moss, cracks on their ancient cloven hooves. A brush stalker’s glamor allows them to look like a mundane deer. But when the glamour falls, the creature devours the light around them and plunges their surroundings into darkness.

Equinox is a small world, ruled by Every Strike of Lightning a Lover Betrayed, the Queen of Shadows. It is her shadow elf scouts and assassins who scour Orden seeking allies who might be persuaded that their lives would be better under a different master. But there are other factions of shadow elves in Equinox. Not all who dwell under the invisible sun seek conquest. Others are sages and pacifists who seek to heal their world or find an empty world somewhere in the timescape to resettle to.

Certain shadow elf warriors have a natural link to the unseen sun that illuminates their world. With this link, a warrior can perform a Lay: a mix of humming and throat singing that aligns celestial bodies across manifolds. Some Lays can temporarily induce an eclipse on the manifold in which the duskcaller is performing, allowing their comrades to gain the advantage.

A skilled duskcaller can lead a band in a group song powerful enough to recreate the conditions of Equinox for a short time. Some shadow elf factions are researching this connection in earnest, considering it a viable step toward terraforming a second Equinox.

Belief that Equinox is a dying world makes the shadow elves desperate, for soon they’ll have no home to retreat to. Their tactics rely on both impenetrable defense and a swift and decisive offense. Since they can’t benefit from a home advantage, all warriors are taught to create one. If there are no places to hide, form them. If the light is too bright, remove it.

In many shadow elf societies, all people are given basic combat training and are expected to serve at least one military tour in their life. Those who excel move on to become duskcallers, mournblades, and eclipses: paragons of strength who are venerated by the people. Research and discovery are employed for the primary purpose of furthering military goals. Even the popular children’s game hide-and-seek is a military device created to prepare a people for constant, imminent conflict.
Most shadow elves speak Illyvric, though platoon leaders might speak some Caelian or Hyrallic.
At the start of any shadow elf’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

linklist.link: Ability: Home Is Where the Hurt Is

id-00112.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00112.traits_name1: The cloak ignores concealment created by darkness. While the cloak is in direct sunlight, they have damage weakness 3. While the cloak has concealment, they have damage immunity 3.

id-00113.effect: The next strike made against the target gains an edge.
id-00113.name: Shadow Elf Sniper

id-00116.special: 5 Malice: Each non-minion ally within 3 squares of the target can make a free strike against them.
id-00116.traits_name1: The assassin ignores concealment created by darkness. While the assassin is in direct sunlight, they have damage weakness 3. While the assassin has concealment, they have damage immunity 3.

id-00117.effect_2: The target takes half the damage and the knightfell takes the other half.
id-00117.name: Shadow Elf Knightfell

notes.p: Children of the Twilight Celestials, the shadow elves are the native denizens of the parasitic manifold of Equinox, also known as Dusk. Theirs is a world of perpetual twilight, a sun that never rises nor sets, a world that knows neither noon nor midnight.
Equinox is a dying world. The shadow elves plan to use their magic to rewrite Orden’s topography, creating a new home with themselves as rulers over all. In

Shadow elves are lit by an unseen sun. In places like Orden, they appear washed out, silhouetted, or grayscale. In Equinox, they have lived in the shadow of their manifold’s eternal dusk, making them incompatible with other light sources. Their skills, magic, and weapons do not fare well in the sun. But in turn, they can blend in with existing darkness and dissolve out of sight.

The shadow elves have mastered the art of combining deep, ancient magic with cutting-edge technology. Their weaponsmiths craft blades of solid shadow that strike and wound in many dimensions at once. A creature hit by one of these blades is injured in multiple worlds at a time. Only a victim of strong mind can compartmentalize and end these effects on their body in the here and now.

When the shadow elves invade Orden, they often ride domesticated dwimmerbeasts known as brush stalkers—quadrupeds who carry entire ecosystems on their rack of antlers. Newly born brush stalkers do not survive translation into Orden, so the ones the shadow elves ride are old: overgrown with bioluminescent moss, cracks on their ancient cloven hooves. A brush stalker’s glamor allows them to look like a mundane deer. But when the glamour falls, the creature devours the light around them and plunges their surroundings into darkness.

Equinox is a small world, ruled by Every Strike of Lightning a Lover Betrayed, the Queen of Shadows. It is her shadow elf scouts and assassins who scour Orden seeking allies who might be persuaded that their lives would be better under a different master. But there are other factions of shadow elves in Equinox. Not all who dwell under the invisible sun seek conquest. Others are sages and pacifists who seek to heal their world or find an empty world somewhere in the timescape to resettle to.

Certain shadow elf warriors have a natural link to the unseen sun that illuminates their world. With this link, a warrior can perform a Lay: a mix of humming and throat singing that aligns celestial bodies across manifolds. Some Lays can temporarily induce an eclipse on the manifold in which the duskcaller is performing, allowing their comrades to gain the advantage.

A skilled duskcaller can lead a band in a group song powerful enough to recreate the conditions of Equinox for a short time. Some shadow elf factions are researching this connection in earnest, considering it a viable step toward terraforming a second Equinox.

Belief that Equinox is a dying world makes the shadow elves desperate, for soon they’ll have no home to retreat to. Their tactics rely on both impenetrable defense and a swift and decisive offense. Since they can’t benefit from a home advantage, all warriors are taught to create one. If there are no places to hide, form them. If the light is too bright, remove it.

In many shadow elf societies, all people are given basic combat training and are expected to serve at least one military tour in their life. Those who excel move on to become duskcallers, mournblades, and eclipses: paragons of strength who are venerated by the people. Research and discovery are employed for the primary purpose of furthering military goals. Even the popular children’s game hide-and-seek is a military device created to prepare a people for constant, imminent conflict.
Most shadow elves speak Illyvric, though platoon leaders might speak some Caelian or Hyrallic.
At the start of any shadow elf’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

linklist.link: Ability: Home Is Where the Hurt Is

id-00117.traits_name1: The knightfell ignores concealment created by darkness. While the knightfell is in direct sunlight, they have damage weakness 3. While the knightfell has concealment, they have damage immunity 3.
id-00117.trigger_2: An enemy within distance makes a strike against the target.

id-00118.effect: If the duskcaller has concealment, they can target one additional creature or object.
id-00118.effect_2: Until the start of the duskcaller’s next turn, the area is filled with darkness.
id-00118.name: Shadow Elf Duskcaller

id-00123.traits_name1: The panther ignores concealment created by darkness. While the panther is in direct sunlight, they have damage weakness 3. While the panther has concealment, they have damage immunity 3.

id-00124.effect_3: The target has a double bane on the ability.
id-00124.effect_4: The eclipse calls forth one brush stalker into an unoccupied space within distance. Each ally within distance can then shift up to their speed and make a free strike.
id-00124.effect_5: Each target loses all their surges. Additionally, until the end of the round, allies ignore edges and double edges on any targets’ abilities, and ignore any nondamaging effects of any target’s damage- dealing abilities.
id-00124.effect_6: The area is shrouded in darkness that creates concealment until the end of the encounter. Any enemy who starts their turn in the area takes 5 corruption damage.
id-00124.name: Shadow Elf Eclipse

When the shadow elves invade Orden, they often ride domesticated dwimmerbeasts known as brush stalkers—quadrupeds who carry entire ecosystems on their rack of antlers. Newly born brush stalkers do not survive translation into Orden, so the ones the shadow elves ride are old: overgrown with bioluminescent moss, cracks on their ancient cloven hooves. A brush stalker’s glamor allows them to look like a mundane deer. But when the glamour falls, the creature devours the light around them and plunges their surroundings into darkness.

Equinox is a small world, ruled by Every Strike of Lightning a Lover Betrayed, the Queen of Shadows. It is her shadow elf scouts and assassins who scour Orden seeking allies who might be persuaded that their lives would be better under a different master. But there are other factions of shadow elves in Equinox. Not all who dwell under the invisible sun seek conquest. Others are sages and pacifists who seek to heal their world or find an empty world somewhere in the timescape to resettle to.

Certain shadow elf warriors have a natural link to the unseen sun that illuminates their world. With this link, a warrior can perform a Lay: a mix of humming and throat singing that aligns celestial bodies across manifolds. Some Lays can temporarily induce an eclipse on the manifold in which the duskcaller is performing, allowing their comrades to gain the advantage.

A skilled duskcaller can lead a band in a group song powerful enough to recreate the conditions of Equinox for a short time. Some shadow elf factions are researching this connection in earnest, considering it a viable step toward terraforming a second Equinox.

Belief that Equinox is a dying world makes the shadow elves desperate, for soon they’ll have no home to retreat to. Their tactics rely on both impenetrable defense and a swift and decisive offense. Since they can’t benefit from a home advantage, all warriors are taught to create one. If there are no places to hide, form them. If the light is too bright, remove it.

In many shadow elf societies, all people are given basic combat training and are expected to serve at least one military tour in their life. Those who excel move on to become duskcallers, mournblades, and eclipses: paragons of strength who are venerated by the people. Research and discovery are employed for the primary purpose of furthering military goals. Even the popular children’s game hide-and-seek is a military device created to prepare a people for constant, imminent conflict.
Most shadow elves speak Illyvric, though platoon leaders might speak some Caelian or Hyrallic.
At the start of any shadow elf’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

linklist.link: Ability: Home Is Where the Hurt Is

id-00124.target_2: Three creatures or objects casting a shadow
id-00124.tier1_6: 7 corruption damage; [R<2] the target has speed 0 (save ends)
id-00124.tier2_6: 12 corruption damage; [R<3] the target has speed 0 (save ends)
id-00124.tier3_6: 15 corruption damage; [R<4] the target has speed 0 (save ends)
id-00124.traits_name1: At the end of each of their turns, the eclipse can take 10 damage to end one effect on them that can be ended by a saving throw. This damage can’t be reduced in any way.
id-00124.traits_name2: The eclipse ignores concealment created by darkness. While the eclipse is in direct sunlight, they have damage weakness 3. While the eclipse has concealment, they have damage immunity 3.
id-00124.trigger_3: An enemy within distance uses an ability that emits light, including abilities that deal fire or lightning damage.

id-00125.name: Brush Stalker

notes.p: Children of the Twilight Celestials, the shadow elves are the native denizens of the parasitic manifold of Equinox, also known as Dusk. Theirs is a world of perpetual twilight, a sun that never rises nor sets, a world that knows neither noon nor midnight.
Equinox is a dying world. The shadow elves plan to use their magic to rewrite Orden’s topography, creating a new home with themselves as rulers over all. In

Shadow elves are lit by an unseen sun. In places like Orden, they appear washed out, silhouetted, or grayscale. In Equinox, they have lived in the shadow of their manifold’s eternal dusk, making them incompatible with other light sources. Their skills, magic, and weapons do not fare well in the sun. But in turn, they can blend in with existing darkness and dissolve out of sight.

The shadow elves have mastered the art of combining deep, ancient magic with cutting-edge technology. Their weaponsmiths craft blades of solid shadow that strike and wound in many dimensions at once. A creature hit by one of these blades is injured in multiple worlds at a time. Only a victim of strong mind can compartmentalize and end these effects on their body in the here and now.

When the shadow elves invade Orden, they often ride domesticated dwimmerbeasts known as brush stalkers—quadrupeds who carry entire ecosystems on their rack of antlers. Newly born brush stalkers do not survive translation into Orden, so the ones the shadow elves ride are old: overgrown with bioluminescent moss, cracks on their ancient cloven hooves. A brush stalker’s glamor allows them to look like a mundane deer. But when the glamour falls, the creature devours the light around them and plunges their surroundings into darkness.

Some Lays can temporarily induce an eclipse on the manifold in which the duskcaller is performing, allowing their comrades to gain the advantage.

A skilled duskcaller can lead a band in a group song powerful enough to recreate the conditions of Equinox for a short time. Some shadow elf factions are researching this connection in earnest, considering it a viable step toward terraforming a second Equinox.

Belief that Equinox is a dying world makes the shadow elves desperate, for soon they’ll have no home to retreat to. Their tactics rely on both impenetrable defense and a swift and decisive offense. Since they can’t benefit from a home advantage, all warriors are taught to create one. If there are no places to hide, form them. If the light is too bright, remove it.

In many shadow elf societies, all people are given basic combat training and are expected to serve at least one military tour in their life. Those who excel move on to become duskcallers, mournblades, and eclipses: paragons of strength who are venerated by the people. Research and discovery are employed for the primary purpose of furthering military goals. Even the popular children’s game hide-and-seek is a military device created to prepare a people for constant, imminent conflict.
Most shadow elves speak Illyvric, though platoon leaders might speak some Caelian or Hyrallic.
At the start of any shadow elf’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

linklist.link: Ability: Home Is Where the Hurt Is

id-00125.traits_name1: The area within 2 squares of the brush stalker is devoid of light and provides concealment.
id-00125.traits_name2: While they have line of effect to the brush stalker, any animal except another brush stalker is frightened.

id-00126.name: Wode Elf Lookout

notes.p: Children of the Sylvan Celestials and masters of the elf-haunted wilds for which they are named, wode elves see all forests as their domain by birthright. They know and enjoy their reputation among humans for snatching children who wander too far into the woods. In their eyes, humans should fear the trees.

Wode elves’ natural ability to mask their presence, called glamor, complements their guerrilla fighting style, letting them strike quickly from cover and then meld back into the underbrush. These traits also make those few wode elves who dwell in cities naturally adept at urban warfare.

The primary value of wode elf culture is respect and reverence for their home, the wode in which they live. They speak of the wode as though it is alive and conscious, dangerous and delightful. Wode elves are receptive to strangers who respect the land upon which they trespass. However, those who seek to harm the wilds ruin their only chance of treating peacefully with the wode’s beating heart.

Wode elves practice a secret technique to use the trees of the wode to craft materials as strong as metal, and to create magical plant creatures that serve them, including the wodenelgs, their trusted mounts. To breathe life into these creations, the wode elves lift their voices in song. The more intricate the song, the more durable and autonomous the creation becomes. A wodenelg’s rider is typically also its singer, creating a connection between the two that lasts a lifetime.

Legends tell of ancient beings, older than the forests themselves, sung to life by an entire wode elf civilization joined in sixteen-part harmony. These beings outlived their creators, and if they truly exist, they now roam the world as unknown and unknowable guardians who answer to nothing but their final set of instructions.

The wode elves’ natural connection to the wode allows them to stay aware of the forest’s goings-on while inside it. This isn’t a telepathic connection, but rather a great understanding of every corner of the wode and a hypersensitivity to changes within it. The stench of a badly set campfire, the sudden squawk of a raven, the forced march of a hungry ant colony: all of this information comes together to form a wode elf’s understanding of their surroundings.

A wode elf develops this sense for their home over time, meaning that a wode elf who lives in an urban environment has just as much understanding of the streets, alleys, and structures of their neighborhood as their cousin in the forest does of the deer paths, streams, and trees.

Not all wode elves are happy to negotiate with peaceful interlopers in their realms. Some groups view even the very presence of such intruders as a direct threat to their way of life. One group of hunters known as the Blightless searches the forest for trespassing mortals, seeking to eliminate their potential threat by any means possible. Overzealous and aggressive, the Blightless also focus on expanding their home’s boundaries, attacking civilizations close to the forest’s edge. Because Blightless attacks constitute the majority of mortal interaction with the wode elves, they set the tone for mortal perception of an otherwise peaceful people.

When wode elves in combat control the terrain, their primary strategy is divide and conquer. Chirurgeons (kai-RUR-jinz) are master strategists who enact their picture-perfect plans in the thick of battle. Enemies will never know how many wode elves they truly face if the crafty chirurgeon can help it.

The warleader of a wode elf court is usually their finest tactician. One warleader alone can command dozens of squadrons across miles of forest with such precision that they can appear to predict an enemy’s movements without ever laying an eye on them. In times of peace, a warleader’s role is primarily that of teacher—a mentor who scouts and soldiers regard almost as an additional parent.

The wode elves send their warleaders into battle only if the situation is dire. Characters who encounter one should be flattered, for the presence of a warleader means the wode elves consider the heroes a formidable threat.
Most wode elves speak Caelian and Yllyric.
At the start of any wode elf’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00126.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00126.traits_name1: Any wode elf within 5 squares of the lookout can make ranged strikes as if occupying the lookout’s space.
id-00126.traits_name2: Abilities targeting the lookout that would take a bane from cover or concealment have a double bane instead.

id-00127.name: Wode Elf Scout

id-00127.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00127.traits_name1: The scout can attempt to hide at the end of each of their turns.
id-00127.traits_name2: Abilities targeting the scout that would take a bane from cover or concealment have a double bane instead.

id-00128.effect: If this ability is used as part of the Charge main action, the runner shifts up to 2 squares first.

One group of hunters known as the Blightless searches the forest for trespassing mortals, seeking to eliminate their potential threat by any means possible. Overzealous and aggressive, the Blightless also focus on expanding their home’s boundaries, attacking civilizations close to the forest’s edge. Because Blightless attacks constitute the majority of mortal interaction with the wode elves, they set the tone for mortal perception of an otherwise peaceful people.

When wode elves in combat control the terrain, their primary strategy is divide and conquer. Chirurgeons (kai-RUR-jinz) are master strategists who enact their picture-perfect plans in the thick of battle. Enemies will never know how many wode elves they truly face if the crafty chirurgeon can help it.

The warleader of a wode elf court is usually their finest tactician. One warleader alone can command dozens of squadrons across miles of forest with such precision that they can appear to predict an enemy’s movements without ever laying an eye on them. In times of peace, a warleader’s role is primarily that of teacher—a mentor who scouts and soldiers regard almost as an additional parent.

The wode elves send their warleaders into battle only if the situation is dire. Characters who encounter one should be flattered, for the presence of a warleader means the wode elves consider the heroes a formidable threat.
Most wode elves speak Caelian and Yllyric.
At the start of any wode elf’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00131.special: 3 Malice: The size of the cube and the potency both increase by 1.
id-00131.traits_name1: Abilities targeting the druid that would take a bane from cover or concealment have a double bane instead.

id-00132.effect: While restrained this way, a target can’t search for hidden creatures.
id-00132.effect_2: While bleeding or weakened this way, a target is covered in lichen.
id-00132.effect_3: The green seer makes a free strike against the target after the target’s triggered action is resolved.
id-00132.name: Wode Elf Green Seer

notes.p: Children of the Sylvan Celestials and masters of the elf-haunted wilds for which they are named, wode elves see all forests as their domain by birthright. They know and enjoy their reputation among humans for snatching children who wander too far into the woods. In their eyes, humans should fear the trees.

Wode elves’ natural ability to mask their presence, called glamor, complements their guerrilla fighting style, letting them strike quickly from cover and then meld back into the underbrush. These traits also make those few wode elves who dwell in cities naturally adept at urban warfare.

The primary value of wode elf culture is respect and reverence for their home, the wode in which they live. They speak of the wode as though it is alive and conscious, dangerous and delightful. Wode elves are receptive to strangers who respect the land upon which they trespass. However, those who seek to harm the wilds ruin their only chance of treating peacefully with the wode’s beating heart.

Wode elves practice a secret technique to use the trees of the wode to craft materials as strong as metal, and to create magical plant creatures that serve them, including the wodenelgs, their trusted mounts. To breathe life into these creations, the wode elves lift their voices in song. The more intricate the song, the more durable and autonomous the creation becomes. A wodenelg’s rider is typically also its singer, creating a connection between the two that lasts a lifetime.

Legends tell of ancient beings, older than the forests themselves, sung to life by an entire wode elf civilization joined in sixteen-part harmony. These beings outlived their creators, and if they truly exist, they now roam the world as unknown and unknowable guardians who answer to nothing but their final set of instructions.

The wode elves’ natural connection to the wode allows them to stay aware of the forest’s goings-on while inside it. This isn’t a telepathic connection, but rather a great understanding of every corner of the wode and a hypersensitivity to changes within it. The stench of a badly set campfire, the sudden squawk of a raven, the forced march of a hungry ant colony: all of this information comes together to form a wode elf’s understanding of their surroundings.

A wode elf develops this sense for their home over time, meaning that a wode elf who lives in an urban environment has just as much understanding of the streets, alleys, and structures of their neighborhood as their cousin in the forest does of the deer paths, streams, and trees.

Not all wode elves are happy to negotiate with peaceful interlopers in their realms. Some groups view even the very presence of such intruders as a direct threat to their way of life. One group of hunters known as the Blightless searches the forest for trespassing mortals, seeking to eliminate their potential threat by any means possible. Overzealous and aggressive, the Blightless also focus on expanding their home’s boundaries, attacking civilizations close to the forest’s edge. Because Blightless attacks constitute the majority of mortal interaction with the wode elves, they set the tone for mortal perception of an otherwise peaceful people.

When wode elves in combat control the terrain, their primary strategy is divide and conquer. Chirurgeons (kai-RUR-jinz) are master strategists who enact their picture-perfect plans in the thick of battle. Enemies will never know how many wode elves they truly face if the crafty chirurgeon can help it.

The warleader of a wode elf court is usually their finest tactician. One warleader alone can command dozens of squadrons across miles of forest with such precision that they can appear to predict an enemy’s movements without ever laying an eye on them. In times of peace, a warleader’s role is primarily that of teacher—a mentor who scouts and soldiers regard almost as an additional parent.

The wode elves send their warleaders into battle only if the situation is dire. Characters who encounter one should be flattered, for the presence of a warleader means the wode elves consider the heroes a formidable threat.
Most wode elves speak Caelian and Yllyric.

id-00132.tier3_2: 6 damage; [P<1] bleeding (save ends); the target has a double bane on strikes (save ends)
id-00132.traits_name1: Abilities targeting the green seer that would take a bane from cover or concealment have a double bane instead.
id-00132.trigger_3: A creature uses a triggered action targeting the green seer or an ally within distance.

id-00133.effect: The target is taunted until the end of their next turn, and the greenskeeper shifts up to 3 squares.
id-00133.effect_2: The area is overgrown with heavy brush and brambles until the end of the encounter, providing cover and concealment for the greenskeeper and their allies. The area is difficult terrain for enemies, and any enemy who starts their turn in the area takes 3 damage.
id-00133.name: Wode Elf Greenskeeper

id-00136.special: 3 Malice: The sentry targets two additional creatures or objects.
id-00136.tier3: 9 damage; the target is marked (save ends)
id-00136.traits_name1: Abilities targeting the sentry that would take a bane from cover or concealment have a double bane instead.

id-00137.abilityname_ability_4: You Will All Witness my Blade
id-00137.abilityname_ability_6: Is It Now or Is It Then?
id-00137.effect: The warleader can teleport up to 3 squares between each strike.
id-00137.effect_2: Each non-minion target can make a free strike, then each target shifts up to 3 squares. A target who has cover or concealment at the end of this shift can attempt to hide at the end of the warleader’s turn.
id-00137.effect_3: The target must not have taken their turn this round. The target takes their turn immediately, and if they have p<2] they are bleeding and take a bane on strikes until the end of their turn.
id-00137.effect_4: The warleader uses Wodeblade against each target and gains an edge on the power roll.
id-00137.effect_5: The warleader can use Wodeblade. Each target can then make a free strike.
id-00137.effect_6: Each target is invisible until the start of the next round. The warleader then uses Wodeblade.
id-00137.name: Wode Elf Warleader

id-00138.abilityname_ability_2: Where I End the Woods Begin

Wode elves’ natural ability to mask their presence, called glamor, complements their guerrilla fighting style, letting them strike quickly from cover and then meld back into the underbrush. These traits also make those few wode elves who dwell in cities naturally adept at urban warfare.

The primary value of wode elf culture is respect and reverence for their home, the wode in which they live. They speak of the wode as though it is alive and conscious, dangerous and delightful. Wode elves are receptive to strangers who respect the land upon which they trespass. However, those who seek to harm the wilds ruin their only chance of treating peacefully with the wode’s beating heart.

Wode elves practice a secret technique to use the trees of the wode to craft materials as strong as metal, and to create magical plant creatures that serve them, including the wodenelgs, their trusted mounts. To breathe life into these creations, the wode elves lift their voices in song. The more intricate the song, the more durable and autonomous the creation becomes. A wodenelg’s rider is typically also its singer, creating a connection between the two that lasts a lifetime.

Legends tell of ancient beings, older than the forests themselves, sung to life by an entire wode elf civilization joined in sixteen-part harmony. These beings outlived their creators, and if they truly exist, they now roam the world as unknown and unknowable guardians who answer to nothing but their final set of instructions.

The wode elves’ natural connection to the wode allows them to stay aware of the forest’s goings-on while inside it. This isn’t a telepathic connection, but rather a great understanding of every corner of the wode and a hypersensitivity to changes within it. The stench of a badly set campfire, the sudden squawk of a raven, the forced march of a hungry ant colony: all of this information comes together to form a wode elf’s understanding of their surroundings.

A wode elf develops this sense for their home over time, meaning that a wode elf who lives in an urban environment has just as much understanding of the streets, alleys, and structures of their neighborhood as their cousin in the forest does of the deer paths, streams, and trees.

Not all wode elves are happy to negotiate with peaceful interlopers in their realms. Some groups view even the very presence of such intruders as a direct threat to their way of life. One group of hunters known as the Blightless searches the forest for trespassing mortals, seeking to eliminate their potential threat by any means possible. Overzealous and aggressive, the Blightless also focus on expanding their home’s boundaries, attacking civilizations close to the forest’s edge. Because Blightless attacks constitute the majority of mortal interaction with the wode elves, they set the tone for mortal perception of an otherwise peaceful people.

When wode elves in combat control the terrain, their primary strategy is divide and conquer. Chirurgeons (kai-RUR-jinz) are master strategists who enact their picture-perfect plans in the thick of battle. Enemies will never know how many wode elves they truly face if the crafty chirurgeon can help it.

The warleader of a wode elf court is usually their finest tactician. One warleader alone can command dozens of squadrons across miles of forest with such precision that they can appear to predict an enemy’s movements without ever laying an eye on them. In times of peace, a warleader’s role is primarily that of teacher—a mentor who scouts and soldiers regard almost as an additional parent.

The wode elves send their warleaders into battle only if the situation is dire. Characters who encounter one should be flattered, for the presence of a warleader means the wode elves consider the heroes a formidable threat.
Most wode elves speak Caelian and Yllyric.
At the start of any wode elf’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00138.traits_name1: The wodenelg ignores difficult terrain and doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks by moving.
id-00138.traits_name2: The wodenelg’s rider has damage immunity 2.
id-00138.traits_name3: If the wodenelg’s rider has the Masking Glamor trait, the wodenelg also has that trait.

id-00139.effect: End Effect: At the end of each of their turns, the cryptic can take 5 damage to end one effect on them that can be ended by a saving throw. This damage can’t be reduced in any way. \n\nSolo Turns: The cryptic can take two turns each round. They can’t take turns consecutively.
id-00139.effect_2: If a target made prone this way is already prone, they are instead restrained (EoT).
id-00139.effect_3: The cryptic reforms their body and appears in an unoccupied space in the area.
id-00139.effect_4: The cryptic slides the target up to 3 squares.
id-00139.effect_5: The cryptic halves the damage, ignores any nondamaging effects associated with it, and shifts up to 3 squares.
id-00139.effect_6: Before using the Dig maneuver, the cryptic moves up to their speed. They then create the burst when they breach the surface.
id-00139.effect_7: Each target makes a Might test.
id-00139.effect_8: The area drops 2 squares and is difficult terrain. Each target enemy falls, while each target ally drops safely. Additionally, each target enemy makes an Agility test.
id-00139.effect_9: The cryptic makes an initial power roll that calls down stone pillars from the ceiling.
id-00139.name: Fossil Cryptic

notes.p: The cave-diving humans who first found fossil cryptics initially thought they were the fossilized reanimated skeletons of creatures predating recorded history. When the explorers’ priest presented a holy symbol and attempted to turn the cryptics, he learned these fossilized bones aren’t mindless undead—and seconds later, he wound up crushed to death by a pillar of stone.

In truth, these living fossil amalgamations are inhabited by elemental spirits. Fossil cryptics are found in places of otherworldly beauty with a connection to an elemental plane of Quintessence, often in caves that have remained untouched for eons or whose tunnels are laced with veins of priceless metal in exquisite fractal patterns. Elemental spirits from that plane inhabit the fossils of creatures who once protected the site, carrying on their legacy. Archaeologists, miners, and others who disturb a cryptic’s domain are ground into dust and subsumed into the creature’s own form.

Though fossil cryptics vary wildly in their chosen shape and form, all contain a central cluster of fossils atop a churning column of rock and metal. With malleable limbs extending from their earthy core, cryptics move with unsettling speed.

Fossil cryptics often warn trespassers to leave their domains, speaking threats in ancient languages before attacking. Should trespassers persist, cryptics weaponize columns of stone at range and can manipulate the ground around them, pushing and pulling friend and foe alike into the best positions for battle.
Many fossil cryptics speak Phorialtic, but they are known to also use the ancient languages of the ruins they inhabit.
At the start of a fossil cryptic’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00139.special_4: 2 Malice: The ability targets one additional target.
id-00139.special_7: A target must be on the ground.
id-00139.special_8: A target must be on the ground.
id-00139.special_9: The cryptic then makes a second power roll that raises stone pillars from the floor. -see No Escape (Cont)
id-00139.target_10: Two creatures or objects on the ground
id-00139.target_4: One creature or object on the ground
id-00139.tier3_10: 4 damage; vertical slide 6; if this movement brings the target into contact with the ceiling, they are restrained (save ends).
id-00139.tier3_2: 15 damage; [A<3] slide 3, prone and can’t stand (EoT)
id-00139.tier3_8: The target moves to the nearest unoccupied space outside the area.
id-00139.traits_name1: The cryptic is constantly surrounded by a 1 aura of swirling debris that obscures their form. Ranged abilities that target the cryptic take a bane. Additionally, any enemy who enters the aura for the first time in a round or starts their turn there takes 5 damage.
id-00139.traits_name2: The cryptic ignores difficult terrain. Additionally, they have line of effect to any creature with concealment if that creature is touching the ground.
id-00139.trigger_6: The cryptic uses the Dig maneuver to resurface.

id-00140.effect: The fireballer can jump up to 4 squares before using this ability.
id-00140.name: Fire Giant Fireballer

notes.p: Supremely well adapted to harsh environments, giants thrive in extreme conditions. Fire giants build floating cities in the hearts of volcanic calderas, while stone giant villages dot the tallest mountains. Most people often go their entire lives blissfully unaware of the local tribe of giants living atop the nearby mountain range. This is for the best, as few “smallfolk” structures can survive even a handful of sufficiently motivated giants.

Giants physically resemble the territory they inhabit. A band of frost giants doesn’t simply live on a glacial mountain—they’re part of that mountain, and it’s part of them. Fire giants exude heat like a roaring volcano. Sages have long debated the question, “Does the environment shape a giant, or does the giant shape their environment?”

Humanoid scholars generally assume that all giants are related, though giants don’t view each other as kin by default. When different giant communities interact, the results depend heavily on the individuals involved and the relationships between their cultures. For instance, stone giants rarely get along with hill giants, as hill giants often detest stone artisanship. Meanwhile, frost giants gladly recruit hill giants into raiding parties if they’re willing to be in the vanguard.

Hailing from sweltering deserts and deep caverns of roiling magma, fire giants embody the passion and ruthlessness of their namesake element. Though they have a reputation for violent growth and expansion, their lesser-known side is a deeply spiritual one, guided by introspection and understanding. Fire giants rarely wear armor, as their bodies heat to extreme temperatures while they fight, causing leather to melt and metal to deform. They instead hone their own bodies into perfect weapons of war.

Born of soaring, frigid peaks, frost giants master their environments to rule mountain ranges and build fortresses of unyielding ice. When frost giants march, a blizzard grows overhead, accompanying them like a war banner. To frost giants, battle is a way of life, camaraderie, and glory. Where frost giants make their homes, a unique form of ice sprouts into flowering crystalline structures. Frost giants harvest this ice, known as issenblau in their dialect, and fashion it into weapons as hard and sharp as steel, which can be used in any environment without melting.

Of all the giant cultures, hill giants are the most likely to interact with humanoids. Hill giants and smallfolk both love to live in places with rolling, fertile fields, and both appreciate the beauty of nature. However, these commonalities can be quickly forgotten if evil hill giants band together to claim the land solely for themselves, or if the smallfolk let fear of the large get the best of them and attempt to drive off their bigger neighbors. Most hill giants want to be left in peace, but when one is pressed, they can demolish a smallfolk village in minutes. Most hill giants spend so much time in quiet peace that sudden flashy sights and loud noises can draw their attention. In battle, such distractions can draw a hill giant’s ire, making them switch from one target to another.

Fascinated by the act of creation, stone giants carve cities out of ancient caverns, mine precious metals and gems, and craft relics worthy of glory. To many a stone giant, artisanship is the highest calling, and all their creations are crafted with an eye to beauty and longevity. Stone giants are made of the same kinds of rocks that form their homes—sandstone, marble, granite, and even basalt. Their stone bodies not only protect them from attack, but also provide them with an additional outlet for self-expression. They often carve runes into their skin, which serve a wide variety of artistic and cultural purposes.
Most giants speak their kind’s dialect of High Kuric. Many hill giants also know Caelian.
At the start of any giant’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00140.target: Each enemy and object in the area
id-00140.traits_name1: Whenever an adjacent enemy grabs the fireballer or uses a melee ability against them, that enemy takes 5 fire damage.

id-00141.effect: The mosstooth can use a creature or object they have grabbed as a weapon for this ability, dealing an extra 5 damage to that creature or object and the target. They then end the grab and leave the creature or object prone in an unoccupied space adjacent to the target.

id-00141.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00141.traits_name1: Whenever the mosstooth targets a creature or object with an ability, any enemy within distance of the ability can use a free triggered action to distract the mosstooth. The mosstooth targets that enemy instead.

id-00142.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00142.traits_name1: The snowblaster is surrounded by a snowstorm. Any enemy who starts their turn within 2 squares of the snowblaster can’t shift.

At the start of any giant’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00143.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00143.traits_name1: Whenever an enemy obtains a tier 1 outcome on a melee ability used against the sand stone giant, they take a bane on that ability until the end of the encounter.
id-00143.traits_name2: The sand stone giant ignores difficult terrain.
id-00143.traits_name3: The sand stone giant can burrow through stone, but can’t drag other creatures underground when they do so.

id-00144.effect: If a target was already slowed, that condition continues but their speed is 0 until the end of their next turn.
id-00144.effect_2: The knife lands in the target’s square, and has 30 Stamina and damage immunity 5. Whenever the knife takes damage, it deals 4 sonic damage to each enemy within 3 squares. The knife lasts until the end of the encounter, and can’t be picked up or manipulated.
id-00144.effect_3: The basalt stone giant moves up to their speed. Each square that they leave during this move is difficult terrain for enemies. Giants ignore this difficult terrain.
id-00144.effect_4: The target is pushed up to 3 squares, or if they have [A<3], they are pushed up to 6 squares and knocked prone.
id-00144.name: Basalt Stone Giant

id-00144.traits_name1: Whenever an enemy obtains a tier 1 outcome on a melee ability used against the basalt stone giant, they take a bane on that ability until the end of the encounter
id-00144.traits_name2: The basalt stone giant ignores difficult terrain.
id-00144.traits_name3: The basalt stone giant can burrow through stone, but can’t drag other creatures underground when they do so.
id-00144.trigger_4: The basalt stone giant takes damage.

id-00145.effect_2: The blaze ricochets, targeting one additional target within 4 squares of an original target and taking a bane against that target, or targeting two additional targets within 2 squares of an original target and having a double bane against those targets. The lightbearer makes one power roll against all targets.
id-00145.effect_3: The lightbearer can target themself with this ability. Each target takes 1d6 fire damage and teleports in a plume of smoke to swap places with the other target.
id-00145.effect_4: The lightbearer emits a beacon of light until the start of their next turn. Each fire giant who has line of effect to the lightbearer has a double edge on abilities.
id-00145.name: Fire Giant Lightbearer

Fascinated by the act of creation, stone giants carve cities out of ancient caverns, mine precious metals and gems, and craft relics worthy of glory. To many a stone giant, artisanship is the highest calling, and all their creations are crafted with an eye to beauty and longevity. Stone giants are made of the same kinds of rocks that form their homes—sandstone, marble, granite, and even basalt. Their stone bodies not only protect them from attack, but also provide them with an additional outlet for self-expression. They often carve runes into their skin, which serve a wide variety of artistic and cultural purposes.
Most giants speak their kind’s dialect of High Kuric. Many hill giants also know Caelian.
At the start of any giant’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00145.traits_name1: Any fire giant targeted by the lightbearer’s damage-dealing abilities ignores the damage and instead regains Stamina equal to the damage that would have been dealt. If the lightbearer moves a fire giant using an ability, they can choose to ignore stability.
id-00145.traits_name2: Whenever an adjacent enemy grabs the lightbearer or uses a melee ability against them, that enemy takes 5 fire damage.

id-00146.effect: A burning creature takes 1d6 fire damage at the start of each of their turns. A burning object takes 1d6 fire damage at the end of each round.
id-00146.effect_2: The outermost squares of the area become a 1-square-tall wall of stone. The rest of the area is on fire until the end of the encounter. A creature who enters the area for the first time in a round or starts their turn there takes 3 fire damage.
id-00146.effect_3: The red fist jumps up to 5 squares. Each creature adjacent to them when they land takes 5 fire damage.
id-00146.effect_4: The target makes a Might test. A target with fire immunity automatically obtains a tier 3 outcome.
id-00146.effect_5: The red fist becomes the target of the triggering ability, then can make a free strike against the enemy after the ability resolves.
id-00146.name: Fire Giant Red Fist

notes.p: Supremely well adapted to harsh environments, giants thrive in extreme conditions. Fire giants build floating cities in the hearts of volcanic calderas, while stone giant villages dot the tallest mountains. This is for the best, as few “smallfolk” structures can survive even a handful of sufficiently motivated giants.

Humanoid scholars generally assume that all giants are related, though giants don’t view each other as kin by default. For instance, stone giants rarely get along with hill giants, as hill giants often detest stone artisanship. id-00146.target_2: Each enemy and object in the area
id-00146.tier1_2: The distance is a 2 burst; 8 fire damage; [M<2] pull 2
id-00146.tier2_2: The distance is a 3 burst; 12 fire damage; [M<3] pull 4
id-00146.tier3_2: The distance is a 4 burst; 15 fire damage; [M<4] pull 6
id-00146.traits_name1: Whenever an adjacent enemy grabs the red fist or uses a melee ability against them, that enemy takes 5 fire damage.
id-00146.trigger_4: A creature within distance willingly moves or shifts away from the red fist.
id-00146.trigger_5: An ally within distance is targeted by an enemy’s ability.

id-00147.effect: Whenever a creature bleeding this way takes damage from that condition, their speed decreases by 1 (to a minimum of 0) until that condition ends.
id-00147.effect_2: The storm hurler throws three size 1L ice javelins into unoccupied squares within distance. Each javelin has 30 Stamina and fire weakness 5. At the start of the storm hurler’s next turn, all javelins not destroyed explode in a shower of icicles. Each enemy and object within 3 squares of an exploding javelin makes an Agility test.
id-00147.effect_3: The storm hurler and the target each shift up to 6 squares while staying adjacent to each other. The target can then jump up to 5 squares and make a free strike.
id-00147.effect_4: The triggering strike has a double bane. If the strike obtains a tier 1 outcome, the storm hurler uses Ice Javelins against the creature who made it.
id-00147.name: Frost Giant Storm Hurler

id-00147.traits_name1: The storm hurler is surrounded by a snowstorm. Any enemy who starts their turn within 2 squares of the storm hurler can’t shift.
id-00147.trigger_4: The storm hurler is targeted by a ranged strike.

id-00148.effect: A target who is already bleeding takes an extra 1d6 cold damage.
id-00148.effect_2: The wind sprinter shifts up to their speed and uses Cold Axe against each enemy who comes within 2 squares of them during the move. The wind sprinter makes one power roll against all targets.
id-00148.effect_3: The wind sprinter and the target each shift up to 6 squares while staying adjacent to each other. The target can then jump up to 5 squares and make a free strike.
id-00148.effect_4: The wind sprinter moves up to their speed and uses Cold Axe against one target.
id-00148.name: Frost Giant Wind Sprinter

At the start of any giant’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00148.traits_name1: The wind sprinter can move through enemies’ spaces at their usual speed. The first time on a turn that a wind sprinter enters a creature’s space, that creature can choose to fall prone or to take 8 damage.
id-00148.traits_name2: The wind sprinter is surrounded by a snowstorm. Any enemy who starts their turn within 2 squares of the wind sprinter can’t shift.

id-00149.effect: If the target is already weakened, they are also bleeding (save ends).
id-00149.effect_2: The area is difficult terrain. Whenever a creature enters a square in the area, they take 3 damage.
id-00149.effect_3: The granite stone giant moves up to their speed and creates a 14 wall of stone in squares adjacent to the path of their movement.
id-00149.effect_4: A 1-square pillar of stone rises 5 squares out of the ground beneath the target, who moves with the ground to its new elevation, then is vertical pushed 5 squares.
id-00149.name: Granite Stone Giant

id-00149.target_2: Each enemy and object in the area
id-00149.traits_name1: Whenever an enemy obtains a tier 1 outcome on a melee ability used against the granite stone giant, they take a bane on that ability until the end of the encounter.
id-00149.traits_name2: The granite stone giant ignores difficult terrain.
id-00149.traits_name3: The granite stone giant can burrow through stone, but can’t drag other creatures underground when they do so.
id-00149.trigger_4: A creature or object within distance moves or shifts away from the granite stone giant.

id-00150.effect: A target who is already prone takes an extra 12 damage.
id-00150.effect_2: In suitably soft ground, the target is entrenched in a 2-squaredeep hole.
id-00150.effect_3: Each target must make either a Might test or an Agility test.
id-00150.effect_4: The target makes an Agility test.
id-00150.name: Hill Giant Clobberer

At the start of any giant’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00150.special_3: The clobberer can choose to fall prone in order to double the forced movement distance.
id-00150.special_4: 2 Malice: A target who would be grabbed by this ability is instead either vertical pushed up to 5 squares; or they take 5 damage, are knocked prone, and can’t stand until the end of their next turn.
id-00150.tier1_4: Grabbed, and the target takes a bane on the Escape Grab maneuver
id-00150.traits_name1: The clobberer automatically destroys any mundane size 1 objects in their path when they move or are forced moved. They can break through any mundane wall made of wood, stone, or a similarly sturdy material this way as long as the wall is 2 squares thick or less.
id-00150.traits_name2: Whenever the clobberer targets a creature or object with an ability, any enemy within distance of the ability can use a free triggered action to distract the clobberer. The clobberer targets that enemy instead.
id-00150.trigger_4: A creature within distance moves or shifts away from the clobberer.

id-00151.abilityname_ability: Marble From a Great Sling 2d10+4 (Signature Ability)
id-00151.effect: If the target has any effect on them that can be ended by a saving throw or that ends at the end of their turn, they are also knocked prone.
id-00151.effect_2: Against a target who is prone or grabbed, this ability has a double edge.
id-00151.effect_3: The ground in the area becomes slick and glossy. Any non-giant who starts or ends their turn in the area is knocked prone and slides 2 squares.
id-00151.effect_4: The marble stone giant halves the damage, and has damage weakness 3 and a +3 bonus to speed until the end of the encounter. The damage weakness increases by 3 each time the marble stone giant uses this ability in the same encounter.
id-00151.name: Marble Stone Giant

For instance, stone giants rarely get along with hill giants, as hill giants often detest stone artisanship. Meanwhile, frost giants gladly recruit hill giants into raiding parties if they’re willing to be in the vanguard.

Hailing from sweltering deserts and deep caverns of roiling magma, fire giants embody the passion and ruthlessness of their namesake element. Though they have a reputation for violent growth and expansion, their lesser-known side is a deeply spiritual one, guided by introspection and understanding. Fire giants rarely wear armor, as their bodies heat to extreme temperatures while they fight, causing leather to melt and metal to deform. They instead hone their own bodies into perfect weapons of war.

Born of soaring, frigid peaks, frost giants master their environments to rule mountain ranges and build fortresses of unyielding ice. When frost giants march, a blizzard grows overhead, accompanying them like a war banner. To frost giants, battle is a way of life, camaraderie, and glory. Where frost giants make their homes, a unique form of ice sprouts into flowering crystalline structures. Frost giants harvest this ice, known as issenblau in their dialect, and fashion it into weapons as hard and sharp as steel, which can be used in any environment without melting.

Of all the giant cultures, hill giants are the most likely to interact with humanoids. Hill giants and smallfolk both love to live in places with rolling, fertile fields, and both appreciate the beauty of nature. However, these commonalities can be quickly forgotten if evil hill giants band together to claim the land solely for themselves, or if the smallfolk let fear of the large get the best of them and attempt to drive off their bigger neighbors. Most hill giants want to be left in peace, but when one is pressed, they can demolish a smallfolk village in minutes. Most hill giants spend so much time in quiet peace that sudden flashy sights and loud noises can draw their attention. In battle, such distractions can draw a hill giant’s ire, making them switch from one target to another.

Fascinated by the act of creation, stone giants carve cities out of ancient caverns, mine precious metals and gems, and craft relics worthy of glory. To many a stone giant, artisanship is the highest calling, and all their creations are crafted with an eye to beauty and longevity. Stone giants are made of the same kinds of rocks that form their homes—sandstone, marble, granite, and even basalt. Their stone bodies not only protect them from attack, but also provide them with an additional outlet for self-expression. They often carve runes into their skin, which serve a wide variety of artistic and cultural purposes.
Most giants speak their kind’s dialect of High Kuric. Many hill giants also know Caelian.
At the start of any giant’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00152.target: Each enemy and object in the area
id-00152.target_3: Each enemy and object in the area
id-00152.target_5: Self and each ally in the area
id-00152.target_7: Self and each fire giant ally in the area
id-00152.traits_name1: Whenever an adjacent enemy grabs the chief or uses a melee ability against them, that enemy takes 9 fire damage, and if they have [M<4] they are weakened (save ends).
id-00152.trigger_4: A fire giant ally within distance makes a strike.

id-00153.name: Abyssal Hyena

notes.p: Edacity. The hyena-faced gnolls know only blood and hunger. These fiends carry with them the evil legacy of an unwitting demonic heritage. Originally from the Abyssal Wasteland, gnolls quickly spread across the timescape, and they thrive in deserts, plains, and other sparsely populated places. Though a gnoll’s muzzle is just as likely to be bloodied by carrion as by prey, their hunting packs hunger for violence, and they eagerly hunt travelers and raid settlements. A pack’s eerie war cry, a wild cackle, presages a night of battle and terror.

The Abyssal Waste is an alien landscape hostile to most life. Yet amid its desolation, fiendish creatures thrive, including abyssal hyenas—bloodthirsty scavengers who fight with other lesser fiends over the corpses of demons. The first gnolls arose when a pack of those predators lapped at the ichor oozing from the wounds of a dying demon prince, As’sylrak the Warper.

As his last act, the demon gave the fiendish hyenas a demonic cunning to match their insatiable hunger, bound his evil will to theirs, and turned their paws into hands so they could wield weapons. He called these new fiends “gnoll,” an Abyssal word that has many meanings, one of which is “to consume completely.” And true to their name, the gnolls immediately devoured their creator.

The merciless gnolls quickly spread across the timescape in search of new victims to quench their never-ending hunger. Their packs were originally followed by some of the abyssal hyenas who didn’t receive As’sylrak’s blessing, with those tagalongs enjoying the castoffs of the gnoll packs. Gnolls never forgot the day when they tasted immortal flesh—and they hunger for more, longing for a day when they hunt the gods themselves through heavenly halls.

Most gnolls live for the thrill of the hunt and the taste of flesh, and they aren’t choosy with their targets. Perhaps the one saving grace for most humanoid communities is that gnoll war bands constantly battle each other for territory, keeping their numbers reduced.

Stronger and smarter than their beastly counterparts, abyssal hyenas crawl out of the Abyssal Wasteland to feed on corpses gnolls leave in their wake. When reinforcements are needed, gnoll spellcasters can use magic to transform abyssal hyenas into gnolls.

Towering among the gnolls of a war band, the elephantine tusker demon serves as beast of burden and war machine. Tusker demons have no facial features except a twisted crown of tusks that surrounds their ravening maw. Although they usually follow gnoll commands, tuskers in lethe (see the Demons section) are prone to violent outbursts and charge at anything that moves—enemies and allies alike.
Most gnolls speak Tholl. Gnoll carnages and other older gnolls usually also know Variac. .
At the start of any gnoll’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00153.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00153.traits_name1: When the abyssal hyena is reduced to 0 Stamina, they can make a melee free strike before dying.

id-00154.effect: The target takes a bane on their next power roll.
id-00154.name: Gnoll Mage Mauler

id-00154.tier3: 5 lightning damage; the target can’t use magic abilities (EoT)
id-00154.traits_name1: Whenever a non-minion ally within 5 squares of the mage mauler is reduced to 0 Stamina, the mage mauler can move up to their speed.

id-00158.effect: A burning creature takes 1d6 fire damage at the start of each of their turns. A burning object takes 1d6 fire damage at the end of each round.
id-00158.effect_2: Two abyssal hyenas claw up from the ground in unoccupied spaces within distance.
id-00158.effect_3: One abyssal hyena target turns into a gnoll marauder, keeping their current Stamina. If any target hasn’t used their own Cackletongue maneuver on this turn, they can use it immediately at no cost.

id-00160.traits_name1: Whenever a non-minion ally within 5 squares of the cackler is reduced to 0 Stamina, the cackler moves up to their speed and can make a melee free strike.

The Abyssal Waste is an alien landscape hostile to most life. Yet amid its desolation, fiendish creatures thrive, including abyssal hyenas—bloodthirsty scavengers who fight with other lesser fiends over the corpses of demons. The first gnolls arose when a pack of those predators lapped at the ichor oozing from the wounds of a dying demon prince, As’sylrak the Warper.

As his last act, the demon gave the fiendish hyenas a demonic cunning to match their insatiable hunger, bound his evil will to theirs, and turned their paws into hands so they could wield weapons. He called these new fiends “gnoll,” an Abyssal word that has many meanings, one of which is “to consume completely.” And true to their name, the gnolls immediately devoured their creator.

The merciless gnolls quickly spread across the timescape in search of new victims to quench their never-ending hunger. Their packs were originally followed by some of the abyssal hyenas who didn’t receive As’sylrak’s blessing, with those tagalongs enjoying the castoffs of the gnoll packs. Gnolls never forgot the day when they tasted immortal flesh—and they hunger for more, longing for a day when they hunt the gods themselves through heavenly halls.

Most gnolls live for the thrill of the hunt and the taste of flesh, and they aren’t choosy with their targets. Perhaps the one saving grace for most humanoid communities is that gnoll war bands constantly battle each other for territory, keeping their numbers reduced.

Stronger and smarter than their beastly counterparts, abyssal hyenas crawl out of the Abyssal Wasteland to feed on corpses gnolls leave in their wake. When reinforcements are needed, gnoll spellcasters can use magic to transform abyssal hyenas into gnolls.

Towering among the gnolls of a war band, the elephantine tusker demon serves as beast of burden and war machine. Tusker demons have no facial features except a twisted crown of tusks that surrounds their ravening maw. Although they usually follow gnoll commands, tuskers in lethe (see the Demons section) are prone to violent outbursts and charge at anything that moves—enemies and allies alike.
Most gnolls speak Tholl. Gnoll carnages and other older gnolls usually also know Variac. .
At the start of any gnoll’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00161.special: 2+ Malice: This ability targets one additional target for each 2 Malice spent.
id-00161.target_2: Self and each ally in the area
id-00161.traits_name1: Whenever a non-minion ally within 7 squares of the marauder is reduced to 0 Stamina, the marauder moves up to their speed and can make a melee free strike.

id-00162.effect: If this ability is used as part of the Charge main action, it deals an extra 4 damage.
id-00162.effect_2: The tusker demon uses the Charge main action and Gore against the target.
id-00162.name: Tusker Demon

notes.p: Edacity. The hyena-faced gnolls know only blood and hunger. These fiends carry with them the evil legacy of an unwitting demonic heritage. Originally from the Abyssal Wasteland, gnolls quickly spread across the timescape, and they thrive in deserts, plains, and other sparsely populated places. Though a gnoll’s muzzle is just as likely to be bloodied by carrion as by prey, their hunting packs hunger for violence, and they eagerly hunt travelers and raid settlements. A pack’s eerie war cry, a wild cackle, presages a night of battle and terror.

The Abyssal Waste is an alien landscape hostile to most life. Yet amid its desolation, fiendish creatures thrive, including abyssal hyenas—bloodthirsty scavengers who fight with other lesser fiends over the corpses of demons. The first gnolls arose when a pack of those predators lapped at the ichor oozing from the wounds of a dying demon prince, As’sylrak the Warper.

As his last act, the demon gave the fiendish hyenas a demonic cunning to match their insatiable hunger, bound his evil will to theirs, and turned their paws into hands so they could wield weapons. He called these new fiends “gnoll,” an Abyssal word that has many meanings, one of which is “to consume completely.” And true to their name, the gnolls immediately devoured their creator.

The merciless gnolls quickly spread across the timescape in search of new victims to quench their never-ending hunger. Their packs were originally followed by some of the abyssal hyenas who didn’t receive As’sylrak’s blessing, with those tagalongs enjoying the castoffs of the gnoll packs. Gnolls never forgot the day when they tasted immortal flesh—and they hunger for more, longing for a day when they hunt the gods themselves through heavenly halls.

Most gnolls live for the thrill of the hunt and the taste of flesh, and they aren’t choosy with their targets. Perhaps the one saving grace for most humanoid communities is that gnoll war bands constantly battle each other for territory, keeping their numbers reduced.

Stronger and smarter than their beastly counterparts, abyssal hyenas crawl out of the Abyssal Wasteland to feed on corpses gnolls leave in their wake. When reinforcements are needed, gnoll spellcasters can use magic to transform abyssal hyenas into gnolls.

Towering among the gnolls of a war band, the elephantine tusker demon serves as beast of burden and war machine. Tusker demons have no facial features except a twisted crown of tusks that surrounds their ravening maw. Although they usually follow gnoll commands, tuskers in lethe (see the Demons section) are prone to violent outbursts and charge at anything that moves—enemies and allies alike.
Most gnolls speak Tholl. Gnoll carnages and other older gnolls usually also know Variac. .
At the start of any gnoll’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00162.traits_name1: The tusker demon can move through enemies’ spaces at their usual speed. When the tusker enters a creature’s space for the first time on a turn, that creature takes 5 damage. The tusker demon can end their turn in a prone size 1 creature’s space, preventing the creature from standing up.
id-00162.traits_name2: While the tusker demon is winded, they gain an edge on strikes, and any strike made against them gains an edge.
id-00162.trigger_2: An enemy within distance deals damage to the tusker.

id-00163.effect: An ally by this ability ignores the damage and can make a free strike.
id-00163.effect_2: Each target deals an extra 3 damage with their next strike until the start of the carnage’s next turn. If any target hasn’t used their own Cackletongue maneuver on this turn, they can use it immediately at no cost.
id-00163.effect_3: The carnage summons four abyssal hyenas into unoccupied spaces within distance.
id-00163.effect_4: Each target moves up to their speed and can make a free strike. Any creature damaged by one of these free strikes who has [M<2] is knocked prone.
id-00163.effect_5: The carnage’s eyes and all exposed blood within distance glow bright red. Each target makes a Presence test.
id-00163.name: Gnoll Carnage

Towering among the gnolls of a war band, the elephantine tusker demon serves as beast of burden and war machine. Tusker demons have no facial features except a twisted crown of tusks that surrounds their ravening maw. Although they usually follow gnoll commands, tuskers in lethe (see the Demons section) are prone to violent outbursts and charge at anything that moves—enemies and allies alike.
Most gnolls speak Tholl. Gnoll carnages and other older gnolls usually also know Variac. .
At the start of any gnoll’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00163.special_5: Until the end of the encounter, all gnolls have a double edge on power rolls that target a winded enemy.
id-00163.target_2: Self and each ally in the area
id-00163.target_5: Each winded enemy in the area
id-00163.tier1_5: The target can’t regain Stamina until the end of the encounter.
id-00163.tier2_5: The target can’t regain Stamina (save ends).
id-00163.traits_name1: Whenever a non-minion ally within 5 squares of the carnage is reduced to 0 Stamina, the carnage can move up to their speed, then can either make a melee free strike against two creatures or use Shrapnel Whip against one creature.
id-00163.traits_name2: At the end of each of their turns, the carnage can take 5 damage to end one effect on them that can be ended by a saving throw. This damage can’t be reduced in any way.
id-00163.traits_name3: If the carnage is reduced to 0 Stamina while there are still gnolls on the encounter map, one gnoll on the map is transformed into a gnoll carnage, keeping their current Stamina.

id-00164.name: Goblin Runner

notes.p: Known among themselves as rogabrin, meaning “more of us” in their Szetch language, goblins are one of the most numerous humanoid species in the world. They can be found across many lands, have developed countless distinct cultures, and dare to venture into environments that few other humanoids are willing to hazard.

Their long arms and prehensile toes make goblins particularly well adapted to environments requiring climbing, and they live equally comfortably in treetop cities as in subterranean realms filled with stalactites, ledges, and chasms. However, just as many prefer to dwell in tight-knit neighborhoods within diverse cities. Many of those goblins who cross swords with adventuring heroes are the worst of their society—thieves and murderers shunned by their own people.

Whether within a society or living in exile, goblins survive and thrive because they work together. A single goblin forced into the wild is terrified. A dozen outlaw goblins are supremely confident—perhaps overly so. Such groups often become bandits who ambush travelers crossing through their territory, be it desert, forest, or underground. Larger goblin hordes might become unscrupulous mercenaries serving powerful villains. No matter how they’re encountered, goblins prefer to fight as an overwhelming force and to flee when foes outnumber friends.

Short, lithe, and long armed, goblins are built for mobility, stealth, and climbing. Goblins who dwell in untamed wilderness and twisting caves utilize their natural agility to hide from threats and flee when found. These crafty skirmishers might run wild through battle, hacking at their enemies’ knees, or unleash arrows as they dart from tree to tree.

Some exiled goblins forge pacts with evil entities for magical power, including archfey, deities, and fiends. Goblin assassins conjure darkness made from the souls of their victims, while goblin cursespitters hurl magic hexes that keep their enemies at bay.

A six-legged winged rodent the size of a housecat, a skitterling moves their clawed feet as they fly, making them appear to scurry through the air. Goblins train these pets to claw at the faces of enemies, as their feet secrete a toxin that causes temporary sluggishness.

Goblins ride enormous arachnids as mounts in battle. With blades attached to their legs, a war spider cuts a swath through enemy forces while archers fire from atop a platform on the animal’s back. During a raid, a war spider arches their body to launch warriors off their back and into the fray.

Some goblins form a special bond with worgs—canine creatures raised by many goblin communities as mounts, guardians, and companions. A worg stays loyal to the hand that feeds them, and will protect their handler to the bitter end.
Most goblins speak Caelian and Szetch.
At the start of any goblin’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00164.target: One creature or object per minion
id-00164.traits_name1: The runner doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks by moving.

id-00165.effect: If the sniper doesn’t use a move action this turn, this ability gains an edge.
id-00165.name: Goblin Sniper

id-00170.special: 1+ Malice: For each Malice spent, one target can be force moved 1 additional square.
id-00170.traits_name1: The stinker doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks by moving.

id-00171.effect: One ally adjacent to the target can make a free strike against them.
id-00171.effect_2: Until the start of the underboss’s next turn, each target gains an edge on strikes, and any strike made against a target gains an edge.
id-00171.name: Goblin Underboss

notes.p: Known among themselves as rogabrin, meaning “more of us” in their Szetch language, goblins are one of the most numerous humanoid species in the world. They can be found across many lands, have developed countless distinct cultures, and dare to venture into environments that few other humanoids are willing to hazard.

Their long arms and prehensile toes make goblins particularly well adapted to environments requiring climbing, and they live equally comfortably in treetop cities as in subterranean realms filled with stalactites, ledges, and chasms. However, just as many prefer to dwell in tight-knit neighborhoods within diverse cities. Many of those goblins who cross swords with adventuring heroes are the worst of their society—thieves and murderers shunned by their own people.

Whether within a society or living in exile, goblins survive and thrive because they work together. A single goblin forced into the wild is terrified. A dozen outlaw goblins are supremely confident—perhaps overly so. Such groups often become bandits who ambush travelers crossing through their territory, be it desert, forest, or underground. Larger goblin hordes might become unscrupulous mercenaries serving powerful villains. No matter how they’re encountered, goblins prefer to fight as an overwhelming force and to flee when foes outnumber friends.

Short, lithe, and long armed, goblins are built for mobility, stealth, and climbing. Goblins who dwell in untamed wilderness and twisting caves utilize their natural agility to hide from threats and flee when found. These crafty skirmishers might run wild through battle, hacking at their enemies’ knees, or unleash arrows as they dart from tree to tree.

Some exiled goblins forge pacts with evil entities for magical power, including archfey, deities, and fiends. Goblin assassins conjure darkness made from the souls of their victims, while goblin cursespitters hurl magic hexes that keep their enemies at bay.

A six-legged winged rodent the size of a housecat, a skitterling moves their clawed feet as they fly, making them appear to scurry through the air. Goblins train these pets to claw at the faces of enemies, as their feet secrete a toxin that causes temporary sluggishness.

Goblins ride enormous arachnids as mounts in battle. With blades attached to their legs, a war spider cuts a swath through enemy forces while archers fire from atop a platform on the animal’s back. During a raid, a war spider arches their body to launch warriors off their back and into the fray.

Some goblins form a special bond with worgs—canine creatures raised by many goblin communities as mounts, guardians, and companions. A worg stays loyal to the hand that feeds them, and will protect their handler to the bitter end.
Most goblins speak Caelian and Szetch.
At the start of any goblin’s turn, you can spend Malice to activate one of the following features.

id-00171.special_2: 2 Malice: Strikes made against targets no longer gain an edge.
id-00171.traits_name1: The underboss doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks by moving.

id-00172.name: Goblin Warrior

id-00172.traits_name1: The warrior doesn’t provoke opportunity attacks by moving.

id-00173.effect: One ally within 10 squares of the monarch can make a free strike.
id-00173.effect_2: Two goblin runners appear in unoccupied spaces within distance.
id-00173.effect_3: The ally is the target of the triggering strike instead.
id-00173.effect_4: Each target can move up to their speed or make a free strike.
id-00173.effect_5: Each ally within 10 squares of the target can move up to their speed toward the target.
id-00173.effect_6: Each enemy in the encounter takes 2 damage for each goblin adjacent to them.
id-00173.name: Goblin Monarch
